Posts.Content: Hi -- I do know that it is very important to stick with one lab, since there can variations between different labs. These #'s can fluctuate, but if you see three successive increases that is usually where a pattern becomes interesting. in my case I was below .02. then .02 and now .06. Trend, all done at same lab, suggests a problem. I, like many others here on this forum I am sure, feel deflated on getting this news, but we need and do press forward...
Posts.Title: 15 month Update - PSA moved from .02 to .06. Concerned...

Posts.Content: My most recent PSA Post RRP (surgery performed 12/11) shows an increase from .02 to .06 over a six-month period. I am 45 and was diagnosed post-surgical pathology as: PT3a (ECE present and focal margins). Gleason 7 (3x4) Pre-surgery PSA was 3.78 Surgeon who performed RRP felt very confident that what post-surgical pathology was detecting on the specimen were simple "surgical artifacts" -- he felt confident that surgery was successful. Given that the RRP was performed in a top NYC hospital and by a leading surgeon I shared his optimism. Now, however, I am experiencing anxiety over this 3x rise in 6-months (rounded .06 = .1). Here are my questions (meeting with my urologist this week to discuss): What is this forum's opinion of movement from .02 to .06? The recent PSA test was taken in the afternoon and all others have been taken in the morning. Would having test performed later in day impact results? I am prepared from surgeon to recommend that I take repeat test in 3 months or so, but this 6-month increase in PSA has me a bit freaked-out and with ECE and focal is time my "friend." Thx.
Posts.Title: 15 month Update - PSA moved from .02 to .06. Concerned...

Posts.Content: Appreciated. Will hope for the drop to .04. Thx!
Posts.Title: 15 month Update - PSA moved from .02 to .06. Concerned...

Posts.Content: Hi - so met with Urologist today and he immediately scheduled me appointments with Medical and Radiation Oncologists. He is also doing another PSA, but with positive margins and a rising PSA we are assuming that the trend is not good. We meet again in a few weeks to review PSA and advice of these Oncologists. Looks like a new round of bone scans and MRI and then SRT. Will keep everyone posted

Posts.Title: 15 month Update - PSA moved from .02 to .06. Concerned...

Posts.Content: Hi - I was 43 at time of surgery and had PSA just under 4. I had 4 of 12 cores positive on biopsy, which like you indicated at the time Gleason 6. I chose surgery, which afterwards on specimen review revealed gleason 7 and positive margins. After 15 months my PSA is now starting to climb so here is more for me to do. My point is 52 is very young and for PC to be in 8 of 12 biopsy samples seems a bit worrisome - so much so that you might want more convincing information about what you are dealing with - surgery answers more questions - brachy not so much. Also, as others have said, T is fuel for PC...
Posts.Title: life after p cancer?

Posts.Title: life after p cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi -- Each person's experience and reaction to this life altering experience is unique. Like you I am in my mid-forties and trying to find balance in a "new normal." I wish you peace and comfort as you sort through this very difficult period of adjustment. Taking care of yourself is perhaps a bit more in your direct control than fighting Prostate Cancer. For me, I would fight with the greatest intensity to improves those things that I might have more control (BP, diabetes) to counterbalance those things for which I have little or no control (PC). But that is me. Perhaps it can be you too.
Posts.Title: 2 years after surgery. single and the effects of surgery related impotence
